description.plain:
Bakersfield friends James “Munky” Shaffer, Reginald “Fieldy” Arvizu and David Silveria formed the funk-rock band LAPD in 1989 and moved to Los Angeles with another friend Brian “Head” Welch as their roadie. Later, with Welch as second guitarist, the band named themselves Creep and recorded a demo with pal Ross Robinson.

However, when Shaffer and Welch visited family in Bakersfield, they met Jonathan Davis who added a darker, goth-tinged edge to the band’s heavy groove. Robinson recalled:

The band wasn’t dark yet; it had, like, killer grooves and good riffs, but there was some happy edge to it. And when (Davis) walked into the room, it went dark and goth. Basically, during the first song, to audition in the rehearsal room, he started freaking the hell out [laughs]. You couldn’t hear his voice, but you felt chills all over your body, and it was instantly like, “Oh my God, yeah – he’s the one.”

They chose the name Korn and recorded four songs inspired by acts like Pantera, Ice Cube, Duran Duran, Cypress Hill, The Cure, Primus and potentially anything in between. That demo attracted Immortal Records. Their debut album only peaked at #72 in the US, but over time became the seed that sprouted into a whole new style of heavy music. Davis explained in 2015:

At the time in rock, there was nothing new or different, and it felt so stagnant. And here come these guys from Bakersfield with this bouncing sound, and I’m screaming my throat out, being super emotional and bringing up all this weird shit … It changed everything, man. And I’m not saying that because I was in the band, but I started seeing kids in baggy clothes and metal kids in Adidas.

Korn’s second album Life Is Peachy began to expand the band’s sound from just dark and serious into frivolity, with a light-hearted cover of “Low Rider” and the band’s first almost-hit in the US “ADIDAS”. The formula worked in the UK where all three singles reached the top 30.

It was the band’s third album Follow The Leader, another collection of dark songs mixed in with jokey ones, that broke the band in the US. Despite having only two moderately successful singles in the US, both reaching the top 20 on two rock charts but not crossing over to mainstream success, the band became what Noisey called “the biggest band in the fucking world”.

With an established and successful sound, the band continued releasing successful albums and playing to packed arenas through the 2000s. But aside from their experimental tenth album The Path Of Totality – a mixing of metal and dubstep – their albums have remained formulaic and predictable. They are still best remembered for their self-titled debut and third album Follow The Leader. In 2005, it was common to refer to Korn as a band whose best albums are their odd-numbered ones:

The received wisdom about Korn is that they deliver on the odd numbers. Album one, ‘Korn’, revitalised metal, dragging it out of the middle ages into the modern era. Album three, ‘Follow The Leader’, took the form into the mainstream, blowing boundaries and preconceptions. Album four, ‘Issues’, was dense and impenetrable.

Welch quit in 2005 after having “Revelation of Christ” and Silveria left silently in 2006, but years later revealed one reason for leaving was that he “was being asked to be a puppet and dumb down my playing” while producers made “cookie cutter Korn songs”. Welch later rejoined in 2013.

The band’s lifestyles have changed drastically over the band’s three-decade career, moving away from the spoils of excess to inspiring others to overcome their addictions and depression. Davis told The Guardian:

Nothing brings more joy into my fucking heart than seeing our music help a kid who is depressed, or suicidal, or going through an episode. That’s the payoff to me, that’s why we keep coming out here, that’s why we keep making records. Because we like to see people smile.

As of 2018, the band has released 12 albums, seven of them have been certified platinum and they are widely recognized as a pioneer of “one of heavy music’s biggest paradigm shifts”. Often Korn is credited with creating the genre of nu-metal, but Davis rejects that label. He explained to Noisey:

I’d like to find that fucking writer that coined that term, nu-metal … Yeah, we’re heavy and downtuned, but metal, to me, is like Judas Priest and Iron Maiden. That’s metal, man. I always thought of us as a funk band, that funky groovy shit.

songs.full_title: Freak on a Leash by Korn

annotatable.link_title: Freak on a Leash by Korn
annotatable.title: Freak on a Leash

body.plain:
“Freak on a Leash” was Jonathan Davis' complaint against the music industry that abuses him, leaving him feeling like “a freak touring corporate America fucking making all the money while it’s taking a part of me.”

The music video was directed by Todd McFarlane, with help from Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, and features animated segments reminiscent of the Follow the Leader cover drawn by McFarlane himself. It won Best Editing and Best Rock Video at the MTV Music Awards in 1999, as well as the Grammy for Best Short Form Music Video in 2000.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRGrNDV2mKc

album.full_title: The Serenity of Suffering by Korn

body.plain:
“Daddy” is the final song on Korn’s groundbreaking self-titled debut album.

Though vocalist Jonathan Davis shouts to the rapist the he/she is doing this to “your own child”, he was not molested by a parent. It was actually a babysitter:

It’s not about my parents molesting me or any of that shit. It was about me being abused by someone else and my parents not really believing me, which I believe happens to tons of kids. I believe tons of kids go back and say, ‘Hey mom, dad, this shit happened’ and they’re like, ‘Stop fucking lying’. Or they don’t understand. And they were real young at the time and I don’t blame them. It was my babysitter, and she has since passed away. Karma’s a bitch.

In 2014, band members and album producer told Rolling Stone that the sobbing at the end of the song is real. Producer, Ross Robinson, kept recording Davis' breakdown and directed the band to resume playing as it continued.

songs.embed_content: Read “Daddy” by Korn on Genius

body.plain:
This song is about a person being abused to the point that they become hollow shell of themself, dealing with suicidal thoughts.
When the song became popular is was often mistaken as “Beating Me Down.

body.plain:
Was released as a promotional single for their third studio album. Though never actually making much of a radio buzz until after the band’s success, the music video was the first video ever to be retired on MTV’s “TRL”, which was a much bigger deal in the 90s.



The track was originally based off of a disco beat and serves almost like a “fuck you” to other metal bands trying to copy their pioneered sound.

body.plain:
“Blind” is Korn’s first single and music video. It was originally written and performed by Jonathan Davis' previous band Sexart, but underwent a number of changes before being recorded by Korn for their 1993 demo Neidermeyer’s Mind and even more changes before appearing on the band’s 1994 self-titled debut album.  It was released along with “Clown” before the album came out, and then re-released as its own single in 1995, the same year the song saw some exposure on MTV in Episode 43 of the fifth season of Beavis & Butthead.

Originally credited only to the members of Korn, on later releases Sexart members Dennis Shinn and Ryan Shuck are also given songwriting credits.

album.full_title: See You on the Other Side by Korn
album.name: See You on the Other Side

body.plain:
“Insane” follows on the heels of the current Korn hit ”Rotting in Vain.”

This track is straight-up Korn heavy, with some brutal Jonathan Davis belting and a bouncing beat bolstered by by a crushing wall of guitars and bass. The song feels like a perfect fit within the band’s catalog, reminiscent of some of their earlier works, especially the main riff.

album.full_title: The Serenity of Suffering by Korn

body.plain:
“Cold” is the second single off of Korn’s upcoming studio LP, The Nothing, released on 2nd August 2019.

Despite the song being experimental, Korn delivers a spectacular instrumental performance enriched by Jonathan Davis' vocals. In “Cold,” the band visualize an empathy less world where they fight with their paranoia.

songs.embed_content: Read “Cold” by Korn on Genius

description.plain:
“Cold” is the second single off of Korn’s upcoming studio LP, The Nothing, released on 2nd August 2019.

Despite the song being experimental, Korn delivers a spectacular instrumental performance enriched by Jonathan Davis' vocals. In “Cold,” the band visualize an empathy less world where they fight with their paranoia.

songs.full_title: You'll Never Find Me by Korn

annotatable.link_title: You’ll Never Find Me by Korn
annotatable.title: You'll Never Find Me

body.plain:
“You’ll Never Find Me” is the lead single off of Korn’s 13th album, The Nothing. The track was released on June 26, 2019 with an accompanying visualizer on YouTube. A music video was later uploaded on July 18, 2019.

Before the track had its final title, it was originally referred to as “Smog Check,” the reason being that guitarist Welch took off early during the recording session to have his vehicle checked out.

“You’ll Never Find Me” also marks the first collaboration between Korn and Smashing Pumpkin’s mastermind, Billy Corgan. Davis told Revolver that Corgan mostly assisted with the vocal melodies for the song. Continuing to recall his experience the the Pumpkin frontman, he commented:

We sat in two chairs like this and he picked up an acoustic guitar and he started playing the chord progressions while I was singing the melodies…I’ve never done anything like that before, and it was a really cool experience."

songs.embed_content: Read “You'll Never Find Me” by Korn on Genius

description.plain:
“You’ll Never Find Me” is the lead single off of Korn’s 13th album, The Nothing. The track was released on June 26, 2019 with an accompanying visualizer on YouTube. A music video was later uploaded on July 18, 2019.

Before the track had its final title, it was originally referred to as “Smog Check,” the reason being that guitarist Welch took off early during the recording session to have his vehicle checked out.

“You’ll Never Find Me” also marks the first collaboration between Korn and Smashing Pumpkin’s mastermind, Billy Corgan. Davis told Revolver that Corgan mostly assisted with the vocal melodies for the song. Continuing to recall his experience the the Pumpkin frontman, he commented:

We sat in two chairs like this and he picked up an acoustic guitar and he started playing the chord progressions while I was singing the melodies…I’ve never done anything like that before, and it was a really cool experience."

album.full_title: See You on the Other Side by Korn
album.name: See You on the Other Side

body.plain: This song is off of Korn’s self-titled debut album from 1994. The lyrics involve lead singer Jonathan Davis’s time in high school where popular athletic kids bullied him for wearing eyeliner and liking new wave music. The number one name he was called: you guessed it, “Faget.”

songs.full_title: Black Is the Soul by Korn

annotatable.link_title: Black Is the Soul by Korn
annotatable.title: Black Is the Soul

body.plain: “It’s me facing my fears head on that’s basically what it’s about. It’s about growing up you know I’m 45 years old 12 years old. Pretty much my life consists making music and playing video games. And then coming home and being a grown up and being a father but I’m just a big kid with me and my boys we all play video games together. It’s just sometimes I have to be a grown up and face my fears, and I’m afraid of everything in the world. It’s about me dealing with things that I have to deal with instead of running away.” – Jonathan Davis

body.plain:
This is Track 11 off of Korn’s sophomore album, Life is Peachy. The title is an acronym for phrase “All Day I Dream About Sex."

It does not have anything to do with the sports brand ‘Adidas’ although in Korn’s early years they famously wore Adidas clothing.

songs.full_title: A Different World by Korn (Ft. Corey Taylor)

annotatable.link_title: A Different World by Korn (Ft. Corey Taylor)
annotatable.title: A Different World

body.plain: “The song is about be­ing in hor­ri­ble sit­u­a­tions and fac­ing pain, want­ing to es­cape to a dif­fer­ent place, a dif­fer­ent world. A place where that shit can’t find you, that’s the gist of the song. Corey came in and did some back­grounds on my cho­ruses. It’s re­ally cool how the song works – it starts and you hear Corey creep­ing in more and more un­til the bridge where he sings, and then it’s just full-on af­ter that.” – Jonathan Davis

songs.embed_content: Read “A Different World” by Korn on Genius

description.plain: “The song is about be­ing in hor­ri­ble sit­u­a­tions and fac­ing pain, want­ing to es­cape to a dif­fer­ent place, a dif­fer­ent world. A place where that shit can’t find you, that’s the gist of the song. Corey came in and did some back­grounds on my cho­ruses. It’s re­ally cool how the song works – it starts and you hear Corey creep­ing in more and more un­til the bridge where he sings, and then it’s just full-on af­ter that.” – Jonathan Davis

album.full_title: The Serenity of Suffering by Korn

body.plain:
“Clown” was one of two songs released in advance to promote Korn’s forthcoming debut self-titled album.



It was later released to radio in 1996 as the album’s fourth single.

Its lyrics were inspired by a concertgoer in San Diego who verabally harrassed the band, telling them to go back to their hometown of Bakersfield. The man later took a swing at frontman Jonathan Davis when Davis knelt down to hear him. The punch missed and the band’s manager took care of the concertgoer.

The name came from the man being covered in tattoos, with Jonathan Davis thinking he looked like a clown with all the tattoos.

The name came from the man being covered in tattoos, with Jonathan Davis thinking he looked like a clown with all the tattoos.

body.plain:
Track 1 on Korn’s 5th album Untouchables.  It won the 2003 Grammy for Best Metal Performance.
The song peaked at #72 on the Billboard Hot 100 and at #4 on the Billboard Alternative Songs charts on May 25, 2002. The song also peaked at #4 on the Billboard Mainstream Rock Songs chart on June 8, 2002.

body.plain: Regarding the song, lead vocalist Jonathan Davis says; “Everyone has someone who hates on you ‘cause you have something they want. It’s really, like, the first empowering song I’ve ever written. The lyrics are: 'You can’t bring me down/I’ve already had my life turned upside down/I ride a downward spiral round and round/But I keep flying, I keep fighting/You won’t ever bring me down.’ That’s like the most positive shit I’ve ever written. And everyone who’s heard it loves it, and I think it’s going to give people who get down on people picking on them and hating them, like, ‘Fuck this! I don’t give a fuck what you think. I don’t give a fuck what you say. You just fuckin’ are a hater.‘ I think people will relate with that.”

songs.embed_content: Read “Hater” by Korn on Genius

It’s really, like, the first empowering song I’ve ever written. The lyrics are: 'You can’t bring me down/I’ve already had my life turned upside down/I ride a downward spiral round and round/But I keep flying, I keep fighting/You won’t ever bring me down.’ That’s like the most positive shit I’ve ever written. And everyone who’s heard it loves it, and I think it’s going to give people who get down on people picking on them and hating them, like, ‘Fuck this! I don’t give a fuck what you think. I don’t give a fuck what you say. You just fuckin’ are a hater.‘ I think people will relate with that.”

You can't bring me down
Already had my life turned upside down
I ride a downward spiral round and round
But I keep flying, I keep fighting, you won't ever bring me down!

I'm good, I'm fine, this life's divine
No hate, no shame, no one to blame

I won't chastise even if you think you can...

I ride a downward spiral round and round

I can't escape from your disdain

But I keep flying, I keep fighting, you won't ever bring me down!

You won't ever bring me down!
You won't ever bring me down!
'Cause I keep flying, I keep fighting, you won't ever bring me down!

songs.full_title: All in the Family by Korn (Ft. Fred Durst)

annotatable.link_title: All in the Family by Korn (Ft. Fred Durst)
annotatable.title: All in the Family

body.plain:
The song From Korn’s 3rd album is a rhyme duel between Korn frontman Jon Davis and Limp Bizkit frontman Fred Durst. Jon and Fred go at each-other’s throats with all kinds of brutal, funny and disgusting insults.

Shortly after the release of Follow The Leader, Limp Bizkit joined Korn on the first season of their long running Family Values Tour, the name of which may have been inspired by this song.

Though this track is sometimes listed as the lead single from the album, it was only released as a demo/teaser version before the first propper single “Got the Life” was released.

songs.embed_content: Read “All in the Family” by Korn on Genius

body.plain:
“Shoots & Ladders” is Korn’s third single. Its lyrics are mainly the recitation of several classic nursery rhymes with a chorus expressing concern about the dark origin and nature of them. Its title is a variation on the children’s board game Chutes And Ladders.

The physical promotional CD single sent to radio also includes the first release of “Sean Olson”, a bonus track not included on the band’s self-titled debut album.

“Shoots & Ladders” was nominated for a Grammy for ‘Best Metal Performance’ in 1996, their first of eight nominations (as of 2018).

It’s notable that “Shoots and Ladders” is the first song in the band’s discography featuring bagpipes, which are played by frontman Jonathan Davis.

songs.embed_content: Read “Shoots & Ladders” by Korn on Genius

body.plain:
Bakersfield friends James “Munky” Shaffer, Reginald “Fieldy” Arvizu and David Silveria formed the funk-rock band LAPD in 1989 and moved to Los Angeles with another friend Brian “Head” Welch as their roadie. Later, with Welch as second guitarist, the band named themselves Creep and recorded a demo with pal Ross Robinson.

However, when Shaffer and Welch visited family in Bakersfield, they met Jonathan Davis who added a darker, goth-tinged edge to the band’s heavy groove. Robinson recalled:

The band wasn’t dark yet; it had, like, killer grooves and good riffs, but there was some happy edge to it. And when (Davis) walked into the room, it went dark and goth. Basically, during the first song, to audition in the rehearsal room, he started freaking the hell out [laughs]. You couldn’t hear his voice, but you felt chills all over your body, and it was instantly like, “Oh my God, yeah – he’s the one.”

They chose the name Korn and recorded four songs inspired by acts like Pantera, Ice Cube, Duran Duran, Cypress Hill, The Cure, Primus and potentially anything in between. That demo attracted Immortal Records. Their debut album only peaked at #72 in the US, but over time became the seed that sprouted into a whole new style of heavy music. Davis explained in 2015:

At the time in rock, there was nothing new or different, and it felt so stagnant. And here come these guys from Bakersfield with this bouncing sound, and I’m screaming my throat out, being super emotional and bringing up all this weird shit … It changed everything, man. And I’m not saying that because I was in the band, but I started seeing kids in baggy clothes and metal kids in Adidas.

Korn’s second album Life Is Peachy began to expand the band’s sound from just dark and serious into frivolity, with a light-hearted cover of “Low Rider” and the band’s first almost-hit in the US “ADIDAS”. The formula worked in the UK where all three singles reached the top 30.

It was the band’s third album Follow The Leader, another collection of dark songs mixed in with jokey ones, that broke the band in the US. Despite having only two moderately successful singles in the US, both reaching the top 20 on two rock charts but not crossing over to mainstream success, the band became what Noisey called “the biggest band in the fucking world”.

With an established and successful sound, the band continued releasing successful albums and playing to packed arenas through the 2000s. But aside from their experimental tenth album The Path Of Totality – a mixing of metal and dubstep – their albums have remained formulaic and predictable. They are still best remembered for their self-titled debut and third album Follow The Leader. In 2005, it was common to refer to Korn as a band whose best albums are their odd-numbered ones:

The received wisdom about Korn is that they deliver on the odd numbers. Album one, ‘Korn’, revitalised metal, dragging it out of the middle ages into the modern era. Album three, ‘Follow The Leader’, took the form into the mainstream, blowing boundaries and preconceptions. Album four, ‘Issues’, was dense and impenetrable.

Welch quit in 2005 after having “Revelation of Christ” and Silveria left silently in 2006, but years later revealed one reason for leaving was that he “was being asked to be a puppet and dumb down my playing” while producers made “cookie cutter Korn songs”. Welch later rejoined in 2013.

The band’s lifestyles have changed drastically over the band’s three-decade career, moving away from the spoils of excess to inspiring others to overcome their addictions and depression. Davis told The Guardian:

Nothing brings more joy into my fucking heart than seeing our music help a kid who is depressed, or suicidal, or going through an episode. That’s the payoff to me, that’s why we keep coming out here, that’s why we keep making records. Because we like to see people smile.

As of 2018, the band has released 12 albums, seven of them have been certified platinum and they are widely recognized as a pioneer of “one of heavy music’s biggest paradigm shifts”. Often Korn is credited with creating the genre of nu-metal, but Davis rejects that label. He explained to Noisey:

I’d like to find that fucking writer that coined that term, nu-metal … Yeah, we’re heavy and downtuned, but metal, to me, is like Judas Priest and Iron Maiden. That’s metal, man. I always thought of us as a funk band, that funky groovy shit.
